title: Tuesday, 1st December, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

PM

PM

thumbs up

really should have sorted that system msg

PM

And I must say

PM

We are all very happy

Relatively speaking.

Well we could do it in pictures

If we must. Go on.

hahahahaha

11:08 am

Anyway. Should we start with the show soon?

PM

guess so

undefined
11:09 am
PM

What's the index doing

PM

??

BE

Up, a bit. Banks mostly.

11:09 am
PM

(Actually...)

BE

FTSE ahead 0.6%, 37 points, at 6393

BE

And we can get the stress test stuff out of the way pretty quickly.

11:10 am
PM

(Now that we have gone ex-Pearson I had promised our recommendation on the stock...)

PM

(has it fallen far enough already? You may well ask)

BE

All banks passed, as expected. Because it's the Cycling Proficiency Test of stress tests.

11:11 am
PM

(12 quid to 832p currently, in little more than a month)

BE

Next year might be tougher, of course, given recent noises from the BOE .......

PM

(Brilliant)

11:11 am
BE

........ as in, counter-cyclical buffers etc.

PM

(So here's our advice on the stock at 832p....)

PM

( Run )

11:12 am
BE

Today, though, the message is dovish. So we're all choosing to forget about 2016.

PM

( Scarper )

PM

( Get out )

11:12 am
PM

( Bin it )

BE

Here's Jefferies.

BE

This year's more comprehensive UK bank stress test revealed strengths and
weaknesses where thought. Results are most positively price-sensitive for LLOY
(9.5% stressed CET1 v last year's 5.3% level). RBS results less relevant given
2015 capital progress. BARC showed a good starting point given African
exposures; STAN still has more work to do. Dovish message from regulator on
future requirements.
All 7 UK banks have passed the stress tests on both CET1 and Leverage basis after the
impact of strategic management actions (STAN & RBS failed leverage before impact, though
the latter's 2015 capital progress renders today's results not so relevant). With regards
to future capital goal posts, in our view the regulator is sending an important
message today: "The FPC is not therefore seeking further structural increases in
capital requirements for the system as a whole."

11:12 am
BE

0% countercyclical buffer. As the BoE has maintained, this buffer is a tool that can
fluctuate with the financial cycle (this will be assessed in March 2016 and the FPC indicates
a mid-cycle buffer of c.1% after gradual increments - our view is that we remain far from
that level and yesterday's two-year extension of the FLS supports our view). Further, the
Financial Stability Report says that "the countercyclical capital buffer that will probably
not change the overall capital requirements for individual banks."
LLOY stress results a positive surprise at 9.5% CET1 (vs year-end 2014 at 12.8%; recall
LLOY had a 5.3% stressed CET1 ratio in last year’s stress test) and should allay fears about
dividend payouts.
STAN weak as expected (5.4% CET1, 3.0% leverage post management actions including
$5.1bn rights issue announced at 3Q), so there is still little room for manoeuvre and
management will likely need to me more aggressive with its balance sheet reduction
programme.
RBS passes CET1 at 6.1% and on leverage ratio, passed by 10bps following
management action. RBS has leverage ratio has improved by 140bps since FY14 to 5.6%
pro-forma for Citizens.
BARC was in-line in our view, with stressed CET1 ratio at 6.8% before management actions
and stressed leverage ratio of 3.2%. Though the latter is impressive given Africa and trading
book were both stressed this year.
What to do? Overall message is that LLOY's sell-off on the back of stress test concerns is
overdone, RBS' target for 1Q17 capital distribution is credible, particularly given the 140bps
increase in leverage ratio YTD 2015. We are buyers of LLOY, RBS and BARC.

PM

( You don't think another profit warning is coming? Oh course another profit warning is coming! )

PM

( I'm not an insider. But I do vaguely have my head screwed on. )

11:13 am
BE

And Deutsche Bank ..........

BE

 The results show that Barclays, Lloyds, HSBC, Nationwide and Santander UK all passed
without any need for further management actions conversion of AT1.
 RBS did not meet the individual capital guidance from the PRA, but it has passed the
stress test after taking into account management actions capital build through the year.
 Standard Chartered did not meet its Tier 1 minimum capital requirement, however the
management actions it has taken (including the capital raise) mean that it now passes the
test. Overall, this test outcome looks most positive for Lloyds (9.5% CET1 ratio after the
stress test), and Barclays (passed the leverage ratio with a 30bps headroom).

BE

A key area in the report this is on the framework of capital requirements. Today's report is
clear in its language on end-state requirements
 Tier 1 equity requirement for the system in aggregate is to be 11% RWAs.
 Leverage ratio requirement is set at 3% for major banks.
 CET1 equity requirement for the system in aggregate is 9.5%. This figure assumes
"definitions of equity resources and risk weighted assets will be corrected" (which we
interpret as Basel 4). There is no mention of mortgage RWAs. The FPC is clear that this is
lower than the 18% estimate made by the Basel Committee post-crisis.
 The countercyclical buffer (which we expect will be on top of the 9.5%) is expected to rise
to around 1% of RWAs and will be kept under review.
 Overall the FPC is "not therefore seeking further structural increases in capital
requirements for the system overall".
 Supervisory equity requirements for individual banks are expected to be small by 2019 on
average but may vary by bank. Phasing of requirements will take into account double-
counting.
 The FPC notes that the banks are currently running higher than the overall sector
requirements which reflects 1) supervisory requirements for specific risks, 2)
shortcomings in RWA definitions and also 3) "banks’ preference to run with some
additional buffer of equity on top of their mandatory requirements. Some part of these
voluntary buffers may reflect uncertainty about the future level of equity requirements.
The FPC is seeking to minimise that motivation"

11:13 am
PM

( And I can tell you it's a screaming sell. )

BE

Overall, this reads more positively that we expected - the FPC is being explicit in saying that for
the sector overall it is not increasing capital requirements further, it has taken into account
RWA definition changes, and is seeking to minimise the motivation to hold additional voluntary
buffers due to regulatory uncertainty. This is a positive, particularly for Lloyds (already at a
13.7% CET1 ratio at 3Q15) where distributions are particularly geared to capital requirements.

PM

( I can tell you what happens next...)

11:14 am
PM

( Having focused the business down and down and down so that it's pure corporatised education...)

BE

Morgan Stanley as well? Sure.

BE

Stress tests – RBS/Standard Chartered in focus: This year's tests revealed
capital inadequacies for RBS (missed ICG) and STAN (missed Tier 1 minimum).
However, in light of management actions neither bank was required to submit
a revised capital plan. Lloyds, HSBC and Barclays remained above 4.5%
CET1/3% leverage thresholds. The charts below illustrate our initial analysis of
the test results. While it's disappointing to see weak results for STAN and RBS,
we expect management action over 2015 to reassure investors that next year's
results will improve (despite a higher bar and potentially tougher test). For
Lloyds, we are encouraged by the comfortable pass without any management
action taken. For Barclays, this year's test proved manageable but, with CET1
thresholds going higher next year and an increase in the stressed CET1
drawdown in this year's test (2.9% vs. 1.6% in 2014), we expect investors to
look for continued capital build. For HSBC a pass is as expected, but interesting
to see more management actions taken this year (70bps vs. 0bps last year),
which may draw attention to dividend sustainability.

11:14 am
PM

( And with corporatised education, er, falling slightly out of fashion...)

BE

FPC measures – CCyB of c.1% likely next year: Countercyclical buffer not
introduced as yet, but strong signal for 2016 introduction. The FPC indicated
that a 1% buffer is appropriate for the next stage in the economic cycle:
"During periods after the recovery and repair phase that typically follows a
financial stress, but before the risks facing the system have become elevated,
the Committee currently expects the countercyclical capital buffer to be in the
region of 1% of risk-weighted assets" and that it will "carefully review" the level
of countercyclical buffer in March 2016. We already incorporate a 1% buffer in
our above-consensus steady-state CET1 assumptions for UK domestic banks of
c. 14%. On buy to let, the FPC remains alert to financial stability risks and will
continue to monitor developments post the tax changes made in the Autumn
Statement.

BE

We expect stress tests to prove tougher in 2016 and beyond as
thresholds rise. As we discussed in our recent note
Boosting resilience Boosting resilience
instead of dividends? Three reasons for caution instead of dividends? Three reasons for caution
, we expect the CET1
threshold to rise from 4.5% towards 9%+ over the coming years. Taking this
year's maximum drawdown of 5% (in line with the stress seen for Lloyds last
year) implies that banks may look to run at 14%+ to give comfort that
thresholds are unlikely to be breached. We continue to prefer banks with the
strongest capital trajectory (Lloyds, RBS), noting that Lloyds still offers c.6%
2016e dividend yield (based on 3p ordinary, 1.5p special).

PM

BE

BE

In our view, today’s release will be taken
positively, due to (1) the absence of any capital
actions due to the stress-test and (2) the lack of
any further macro-prudential measures. Although
no increase was announced today, we see Lloyds
and RBS as most exposed to any gradual increase
in the CCyB. However, given their current capital
positions, they should be able to absorb an
increase to the flagged c.100bp level

11:18 am
BE

And UBS .....

BE

The FPC did not increase capital requirements or impose underwriting curbs on specific
parts of the lending market. There had been some market concerns that buy-to-let
lending may see significant capital increases today. Though the FPC "remains alert" to
risks here it is monitoring BTL following tax changes imposed rather than imposing new
requirements now. Stamp duty changes are applicable from April 2016, interest
deductibility rules change in 2017. Though a tougher regulator climate may yet
emerge, the lack of action here should be positive for Paragon (Buy) and the
other challengers.

PM

( You know, no one at the FT will say this -- cos they good people and polite.. )

11:18 am

OneSavings Bank PLC (OSB:LSE): Last: 378.80, down 5.9 (-1.53%), High: 385.00, Low: 374.50, Volume: 85.29k
BE

Ian Gordon's argument was that BTL lending's restricted by OSB's balance sheet, not by the size of the market.

11:20 am
PM

( But the reality is that Pearson's ownership blunted and stunted the FT. )

BE

The market agreed, belatedly, and now he says it's in the price.

BE

Here's the upshot.

11:21 am
BE

OneSavings shares fell 16% in 6 days, but have since rallied by 13% in just 3 days. Our view on outlook and valuation improves by virtue of the FLS extension; our target price rises to 380p (from 375p). However, this level has already been surpassed, so we downgrade back to Hold (from Buy). We continue to regard OSB as an outstanding (albeit capital constrained) growth story, but one which we think is again fairly valued. We recommend a switch into Virgin Money (Buy) or Aldermore (Buy) which, in our view, are not.

For OneSavings, our forecasts now reflect incremental benefit from the FLS extension, i.e. small reductions in our Interest Expense estimates in 2016/17e. As discussed in our report, Ask the wrong question…get the wrong answer! (26 November), we continue to model strong buy-to-let-led loan growth of £1.2bn (31%) in 2015e, £1.1bn (22%) in 2016e and £1.2bn (19%) in 2017e.
In 2015e, with an improving Net Interest Margin and cost:income ratio, we forecast EPS of 34.3p (+59%). Thereafter, notwithstanding the introduction of the UK corporation tax “surcharge” from January 2016, and with greater stability in the cost:income ratio and NIM, we forecast EPS of 39.8p (+16%) in 2016e and 45.9p (+15%) in 2017e.
OneSavings’ premium valuation has been restored. It trades on 3.7x H1 2015 tNAV with our forecast RotE of 32% in 2015e declining to 27% by 2017e. The majority shareholder’s residual 57% stake is not subject to any current lock-up.
Within the UK “challenger bank” space, we see superior upside for Virgin Money, trading on 8.1x 2017e EPS, supported by strong growth in the (mainstream) mortgage market and its huge capital surplus (CET1 ratio 18.7% at H1 2015); see discussion in our report, Mortgage approvals continue to surge in October (25 Nov). We also see strong upside potential for Aldermore, on 6.7x 2017e EPS, supported by strong broad-based mortgage-led growth (including both “professional” and “amateur” buy-to-let), see discussion in our report, More record mortgage data: just keep it coming…(19 Nov).
We downgrade OSB to Hold (from Buy). TP raised to 380p (from 375p).

PM

(If you look back to the late 90s, the FT had all the bits to construct Bloomgerg. )

PM

( Had a world class consumer offering in the form of the paper )

11:22 am
PM

(But it also had a newswire, and an online markets business -- Market Watch.)

BE

Should we move on to other matters?

undefined
11:22 am
PM

(It had data, in the form of IDC)

PM

(Had Extel. Had what became factiva.)

PM

(Had a huge EM news business.)

11:22 am
BE

Okay ............. I think I have to do a quick bit of de-RAW here.

PM

(And what did Pearson management do? They sold it all off, piecemeal. )

BE

What's the opposite of RAW? Cooked, obviously, but that isn't quite right in context.

11:23 am
BE

Anyway, National Grid.

National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 929.20, up 3.4 (+0.37%), High: 930.90, Low: 920.10, Volume: 1.68m
BE

So, Bloomberg ran this overnight ...

11:23 am
BE

U.S. electricity-transmission company ITC Holdings Corp. is exploring a sale, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Shares rose as much as 13 percent, the biggest intraday jump in more than a decade.
The Novi, Michigan-based power network is working with financial advisers to seek potential buyers, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the process is private. ITC’s shares closed up 9.3 percent to $36.88 in New York, lifting its market value to more than $5.6 billion.
Utilities companies including the U.K.’s National Grid Plc and Spain’s Iberdrola SA may consider bidding for ITC, according to other people familiar with the situation. The deliberations are at an early stage and may not lead to a sale, the people said.

BE

Coincidentally, we were chasing the same story from a slightly different angle.

BE

The rumour that reached us was that National Grid was working on a bid of around $45 a share for ITC ...

11:24 am
PM

(People here complained of a lack of investment from Pearson. Investment??? They were sucking the life-blood out of the thing. )

BE

... However, that would all appear to be very, very premature..

BE

What we can say with some confidence is that National Grid's in the ITC auction process, which kicked off a week ago ...

11:25 am
BE

But NG only appointed a new CEO at the start of the month, and is in transition between the old guy and the new guy for the rest of the year.

BE

And NG's balance sheet doesn't make ~$7bn-ish deals look very easy.

BE

So. If National Grid's involved ...

11:25 am
BE

... It's much more likely to be in there to look at the numbers of a rival, rather than to launch an offer.

PM

(Sure, there was one short period, during the dot comedy, that the FT was allowed to expand. It was a disaster, timing wise. But Pearson made up all the associated losses with one disposal -- Market Watch. That covered everything.)

BE

Also, note, there's no shortage of potential bidders. It's a crowded process.

11:26 am
PM

(Anyway, ive said enough. We're under new ownership now. )

PM

( Sell Pearson )

BE

Also likely to be in there are Berkshire Energy, Iberdrola's Avangrid, Hydro One, NextEra Energy, American Electric Power ....

11:26 am
BE

Midcap regulated utilities tend to sell for between 20 and 28 times earnings

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

So, using $2.20 EPS in 2017, we get a baseline valuation of $44 a share. That leaves a bit on the table for ITC holders, but not much.

11:27 am
BE

Whatever, NG shares flat this morning so I guess the market's taking this rationally.

undefined

On Drax .................

BE

11:36 am
undefined
BE

Right, yeah, this Drax story's quite dull.

BE

RWE gets EU approval for a biomass conversion.

11:37 am
BE

Positive for RWE, positive for Drax on the readacross.

BE

BRUSSELS (Reuters) - Britain secured European Union regulatory approval on Tuesday for its plan to finance the conversion of a coal plant at Lynemouth, northern England, to biomass.
The European Commission said a nine-month investigation showed that the project was in line with the 28-country bloc's environmental and energy goals.
"The project's contribution to the European renewable energy and CO2 emissions reduction targets clearly outweighs any potential distortions of competition that could be triggered by the state support," the EU executive said in a statement.
Lynemouth Power, a subsidiary of RWE Supply and Trading, operates the coal-fired plant. UK authorities will grant aid to the plant until 2027. The biomass facility is expected to use about 1.5 million tonnes of wood pellets annually to generate 420 megawatts of electricity.

PM

hmm

undefined

Please join us at the main desk.... )

BE

n Cut to Sell, £10 TP — While Babcock is an excellent operator with solid barriers to entry in a growing market, we currently see too many risks for comfort around its shares’ investment case. Top-line and succession risk are added to our previous concerns around margins and cashflow. We trim our 2017E and 2018E EPS forecasts by -2%, lower our target price to 1000p and downgrade to Sell..

PM

(Dont worry Boncoeur, im a short arse)

11:41 am
BE

n Organic growth risk — With both Magnox and QE Carrier growth props heading into reverse (combined £160m headwind), FY17 looks a year of deceleration and we model a worse organic growth outcome than management’s “high single digits” outlook. We assume 100%-owned Babcock continues at its current and mediumterm 5-6% organic growth rate but with Magnox JV sales step-down diluting total organic growth to 3.5%, well below management guidance.

BE

n Cash conversion risk — With capex running almost twice depreciation, plus provisions and working capital outflows, Babcock has gone from “Cashflow King” to one of the sector’s weakest cash converters of earnings at c70%.
n Management succession risk — In addition to Support Services head Kevin Thomas’s retirement, we expect long-time CEO Peter Rogers also to retire over the next 6-9 months.
n 1000p Target Price — Lowered from 1020p, our valuation remains based on sector average EV/EBITA multiples and a DCF.

BE

(@Boncoeur: I'm quite tall, but I've rarely been called a poppy, so the threat looks manageable)

11:42 am
undefined
BE

And here's that Jefferies note on oil, as requested.

PM

You spoil them Bryce

11:44 am
BE

Yeah, it's a kind of good-cop-bad-cop act .....

BE

.... except it's one where I talk about stocks and you rant in brackets about our ex employer.

BE

It works, though. Sort of.

11:44 am
BE

Here's Jefferies' cover page.

BE

There are signs of industry generated valuation support for Euro E&P at current
levels. This may seem inconsistent with a sector still requiring $75/boe to justify
our NAV target prices. However, "self help" cost cutting allows virtually all
to survive & some to flourish at lower oil prices but only with deferral of
unsanctioned projects. In a $50/b world, Lundin Petroleum (Top Pick) is the
clear Free Cash Flow winner even with committed Johan Sverdrup capex.
Winners in a "low" oil price world (LUPE, Top Pick, Buy, Skr157 PT). Running mid-
cap E&P's at $50/b through to 2020 shows LUPE, DETNOR & SIA as the only ones generating
free cash flow. We upgrade SIA to Hold (from Underperform). While SIA's cash flow profile
comes as no surprise to us, the stock has also fallen in line with our unchanged 135p price
target. LUPE & DETNOR offer sanctioned development growth in parallel to +ve FCF, but we
retain a preference for LUPE as the way to play Norway's Johan Sverdrup development.
Industry generated valuation support (TLW, Hold, 215p PT). The valuation
question in our September upgrade of TLW to Hold from Underperform was "how much
value to ascribe to Kenya?" Maersk Oil's recent farm-in to Kenya further supports that rating
upgrade by providing a valuation uplift to an unsanctioned discovery/development.

BE

The role of industry in finding a bottom. While we recognise overly bullish analyst
NAV's in times of "high" oil price (including ourselves in that qualification), we also caution
against overly bearish NAV's run at the current oil price - that may not be someone else's
view of the asset in question or their view of the future price of oil.
But industry support is no given - self help is crucial. Cost cutting is possible for all
companies to maintain or even pay-down net debt levels. PMO (Buy 120p) deferring Sea
Lion is the best example. For E&P's with "net cash" following disposals and with valuations
dominated by either unsanctioned development (OPHR) or early stage discoveries (CNE),
the ability to be FCF neutral is unrealistic. However FCF analysis suggests OPHR (Hold, 105p)
has to attract an upstream farm-in, in our view, to fund the Fortuna FLNG project. Whereas
CNE (Buy, 175p) could attract Senegal debt funding due to reasonable gearing.

11:50 am
BE

PM

Thomas Adolff and team

PM

China, MOFCOM and LNG
There is significant speculation in the press on LNG matters with a particular
focus on specific contracts with buyers from India and China, and whether
contractual changes will have a knock-on effect in the industry as a whole. We
will briefly recap our view on potential remedies applied to the RDS/BG deal by
MOFCOM (China). We view these hurdles as manageable (contrary to some
press speculation) and that contract sanctity here will be broadly respected

11:50 am
PM

They're relaxed

PM

Definition of Contracts. Chinese and Western ideas of written contracts
can differ. The Chinese often view the signing of a contract as merely the
'beginning' of a relationship. A commitment to a relationship is, however,
highly valued, which could explain why the infamous NWS LNG contract into
China (one of the worst LNG contract from a sellers' perspective) is still
going since inception. Thus, we view RDS' relationship with Chinese NOCs
generally as mature and long lasting, but also mutually beneficial as a whole.
■ MOFCOM. If any (behavioural) remedies are applied, then it is most likely
related to LNG, as similar to Glencore / Xstrata and Marubeni /Gavilon, the
remedies were related to a commodity, on which the Chinese relied upon
and imported from these companies. There were different types of remedies,
both 'structural' (asset sales/farm down) and 'behavioural'. Behavioural
remedies can come in the form of contractual changes, which in the two
cases were on a 'temporary', not 'permanent', basis. Often MOFCOM (the
regulator), bases its remedies on feedback from the Chinese SOEs –
RDS/BG have strong relationships with both PetroChina and CNOOC.

PM

LNG contract. The 'bread and butter' of any LNG project is contract sanctity.
A seller might be willing to provide some flexibility beyond the SPA terms for
a 'temporary' period, but it is important that it does not give into adjusting the
ToP and pricing formulas (outside of price revision clauses). The press in
recent months has widely talked about MOFCOM potentially requesting
changes to pricing formulas, higher DQT than the typical 10% (we would
think of it as 'accelerated' with the cumulative limit, typically 50% of 1 year's
ACQ unchanged), lowering import volumes per year via extending the term
of existing deals etc. For what it's worth, most of the RDS supply into China
is with partners (in JV format); i.e. others would have to agree to changes to
terms, not just RDS – this looks unlikely. Gorgon and BG's CNOOC contract
look to be the exception. We view changes to pricing formula as unlikely.
Other 'temporary' changes are manageable from a portfolio perspective.

11:51 am
PM

Bottom line, it may not be 'unconditional', in our view; MOFCOM may apply
remedies similar to other 'commodity' related deals, albeit ones that are
'manageable', and more so given RDS' strong relationship with the SOEs
that influence such remedies. We see its relationship as one of the most
robust, but struggle to see that being enough to allow for an 'unconditional'
approval, particular in the context of the challenges the Chinese are going
through, most notably in LNG, where it is temporarily over-contracted

BE

And begins by quoting us, which is a good indicator of solid research.

BE

We upgraded to Buy in September as we felt risk/reward had become
favourable. According to The Financial Times this contrarian call was “very
brave” but two months on, and ahead of a year end trading update, our
conviction is increasing. Headwinds have not fully abated, but the IMS will
highlight the significant progress made by new management in 2015.

BE

FY16E attrition guidance could increase to £400m. Earlier this year, Serco guided to
£350m revenue attrition in FY16E. In our view, this could be revised to c£400m as the original
figure included £50m from Intelenet (which drops out as it will be sold before year end)
and the following contracts have been lost or lapse: US National Benefits Centre (£35-40m
annual revenue); Virginia Department of Transport (c£35m annual revenue, winding down
towards a May 2016 exit); complex cases child maintenance (£30m annual revenue which
runs off over three years as existing cases are resolved).
Disposal update. Judging by Blackstone’s recent financing activities the Intelenet
acquisition is on track to complete before year end. This leaves UK leisure/waste as Serco’s
sole remaining non-core asset, but novating its contracts to individual legal entities could
take until mid-2016. Serco’s balance sheet will have been de-risked by then, and we think its
turnaround will have a firmer footing so there may be a case for retaining this public sector
facing unit.
Positive cashflow developments. Serco recently reached a favourable agreement with
the Australian government to amend its contract to provide in-service support to Armidale
Boats. This is the largest component of the £447m onerous contract provision and resolving
loss makers would lead to material FCF upgrades. On recovered earnings, Serco has an 8%
FCF yield.
Trimming LFL revenue assumptions; unchanged EPS. We now anticipate -8% and
+2% organic revenue growth in FY16E and FY17E, respectively (previously -5% and +3%)
due to higher attrition, but our EPS estimates remain unchanged for two reasons: 1) as we
highlighted in our September note, management feel more in control of cost efficiencies;
2) we assumed that UK leisure/waste would be sold in late 2015 but have reconsolidated
until any transaction is clearer.
